Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to **Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28**, which authorizes the Probate and Family Court to modify a judgment concerning the custody of a minor child upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where such modification serves the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: See also **G.L. c. 208, § 31** and **G.L. c. 209C, § 10(b)** (defining custody determinations and best-interest factors).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(b).proposition: See also **G.L. c. 208, § 31** and **G.L. c. 209C, § 10(b)** (defining custody determinations and best-interest factors).

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: See **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) (emphasizing that the child’s best interests govern all custody determinations).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames both custody and removal determinations in terms of the child’s best interests as the governing standard. It construes the removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the child’s best interests, and emphasizes that although the custodial parent’s interests are relevant, the child’s best interests remain the paramount concern. Thus it supports the proposition that the child’s best interests govern custody determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … [t]he words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent…’”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: See **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (modification warranted where the living or parenting arrangements no longer serve the child’s welfare).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30 with parents sharing joint physical custody. It applies a best-interests standard to decide whether to permit removal; it does not discuss or hold that a modification of custody is warranted whenever living or parenting arrangements no longer serve the child’s welfare. In fact, the court denies both the mother’s request to relocate and her request for sole physical custody, and maintains shared custody, so it is not authority for the quoted modification principle.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below. On the facts in this case, the judge appropriately considered the ‘best interests’ of the children, and did not abuse her discretion in concluding that removal of the children would not serve their best interests.”

Doe v. Doe, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1983).raw_text: Doe v. Doe, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1983)
Doe v. Doe, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1983).proposition: See **Doe v. Doe**, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1983) (joint custody requires substantial cooperation between parties, and breakdown of communication constitutes changed circumstances).
Doe v. Doe, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1983).support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss whether conflict between parents can preclude joint custody, but it does not state that joint custody requires substantial cooperation nor that a breakdown of communication itself constitutes a change in circumstances. Instead, the court distinguishes Rolde v. Rolde and finds that despite interpersonal conflict and inability to communicate, the conflict did not involve disagreements about the child’s care and thus did not make joint custody inappropriate. The case also does not treat any communication issues as a ‘changed circumstance’ for modifying custody; it affirms the existing joint custody order.
Doe v. Doe, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1983).relevant_excerpt: “In contending that the conflict between the parties precludes an award of joint custody, the husband relies upon Rolde v. Rolde… where the court agreed with the trial judge’s observation that ‘in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually “to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.”’ … We think that Rolde is inapplicable on these facts and that the probate judge was justified in concluding that any existing conflict between the parties is not of the type which would render the joint legal and physical custody award inappropriate for David.”}

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.proposition: See **Rosen v. Rosen**, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016) (court has broad discretion to modify orders upon evidence of material change impacting child’s education or welfare).
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss broad judicial discretion to modify orders upon a material change impacting a child’s education or welfare. Instead, it narrowly addresses whether a judge may, in very limited equitable circumstances, apply a credit against child support arrearages without violating the statutory bar on retroactive modification, and also addresses termination of support and allocation of college expenses already being incurred. It does not articulate a general standard about modifying orders based on a material change in circumstances regarding a child’s education or welfare, so the proposition overstates and mischaracterizes the holding.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Consistent with the views of other jurisdictions, we conclude that a judge is not foreclosed by G. L. c. 119A, § 13(a), from determining whether ‘compelling circumstances of an equitable nature’ warrant the allowance of a credit for the payor’s fulfillment of his or her child support obligation ‘in a manner other than as directed by the original order’ but which nevertheless accomplishes the maintenance of the child as envisioned by the original order. … We stress that the concept of equitable credit is an extremely narrow exception to the general rule that support must be paid in the manner originally ordered.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: See **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003) (“best interests” standard is overarching and flexible to meet evolving circumstances).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The court undertakes an extended discussion of the history and nature of the “best interests of the child” standard, emphasizing its long-standing role as the touchstone in custody decisions and that it remains the governing, overarching inquiry even after the enactment of G.L. c. 209C. The opinion further explains that the statute’s specific factors do not replace or limit the best-interests standard, thereby confirming that the standard is flexible enough to accommodate and respond to evolving circumstances and a range of relevant considerations.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since… In spite of its widespread use as an appropriate standard for custody determinations, the ‘best interests of the child’ formulation has been criticized… As a remedy… Legislatures, courts, and commentators have adopted or proposed a number of constraints… The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: See **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981) (court will consider a child’s stability and academic performance in custody decisions).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion thoroughly discusses the best-interests-of-the-child standard and emphasizes factors like the primary nurturing parent, strength of the parent-child bond, parental conflict, and ability to cooperate on child-rearing. However, it does not specifically mention the children’s stability in terms of continuity of environment or their academic or school performance as explicit considerations. Because those particular aspects are not identified or analyzed in the custody discussion, the case does not clearly support the proposition as phrased.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: See **Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) (shared legal custody appropriate only where parents can cooperate in matters affecting the child’s welfare).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses physical custody and best-interests factors, but it does not address the legal standard for awarding shared or joint legal custody in terms of parental cooperation. There is no language stating that shared legal custody is appropriate only where parents can cooperate in matters affecting the child’s welfare. The case affirms a specific custody allocation based on parental conduct and stability, not on a general rule limiting joint legal custody to cooperative parents.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: "In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is 'best for the child'... The judge must weigh 'all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.' ... Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable... and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent."

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: See **Schechter v. Schechter**, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015) (consistent parental refusal to support child’s educational needs supports modification).
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The Schechter opinion is an appeal from a divorce and 209A order; it addresses custody, visitation suspension, removal, a prenuptial agreement, and attorney’s fees. It does not discuss modification standards or a parent’s refusal to support a child’s educational needs as a basis for modifying an existing order. The holdings on custody and visitation turn on domestic violence, coercive control, and the child’s best interests, not on educational support, so the case does not provide authority for the cited proposition.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, the judge made findings that the father was domineering in his relations with the mother and child… The judge’s decision to suspend visitation for one year is also supported by his extensive findings that over the course of their relationship, the father had engaged in physical, emotional, and financial abuse of the mother, and, in his interactions with the child, had damaged the mother’s relationship with the child. See G. L. c. 208, § 31A.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998),.raw_text: Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998), cert. denied sub nom. Hugo P. v. George P., 526 U.S. 1034 (1999)
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998),.proposition: See **Adoption of Hugo**, 428 Mass. 219 (1998), cert. denied sub nom. Hugo P. v. George P., 526 U.S. 1034 (1999) (court must emphasize the child’s welfare as paramount).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998),.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the governing standard in adoption and custody decisions as the child’s “best interests” and applies that standard as the controlling consideration once parental unfitness is found. While it does not use the exact word “paramount,” it clearly treats the child’s welfare/best interests as the decisive, overarching criterion in choosing between competing adoption plans, thus supporting the substance of the cited proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998),.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … Presented with more than one potential adoption placement, the judge’s task is to determine which plan will serve the best interests of the child…”
